description.narrative: Joint Programme on Youth Employment is a flagship intervention of the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) and UN for creation of employment opportunities for the young women and men, under Peace and State-building Goal-4 (Economic Foundations).

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

description.narrative: Output 1.1 1. Dried fish market study produced 2. # of government-agreed interventions for upgrading value chains. 3. # of young men and women start-up companies created 4. # of young men and women trained in solar energy Output 1.3: 1. Number of work-months/days created through short-term jobs (at least 30% women) 2. Amount injected into local economy (through wages)

comment.narrative: - No value chain development studies are available in fisheries, solar, construction and other productive sectors. - 0 - 0

(a) 24 fish enterprises set up/strengthened in Bossaso (12), Kismayo (6) and Berbera (6); (b) 120 youth (50% women) employed in 24 fish enterprises (c) HACCP guidelines on seafood safety in Jubaland, Puntland and Somaliland developed and endorsed as well as 50 government officials and youth entrepreneurs trained in sea food safety; (d) 400 unemployed and underemployed youth (200 from Mogadishu, 100 from Kismayo and 100 from Baidoa (with 50% women) trained in solar technology and business development skills; (e) 50 trained youth (50% women) employed and earning adequate income through job placement scheme; (f) 50 trained youth (50% women) self-employed and earning adequate income by setting up/strengthening their 20 businesses - Mogadishu (12 SMEs, involving 36 youth, and Kismayo (4 SMEs, involving 12 youth); (g) Number of households accessing affordable off-grid solar energy, disaggregated by sex. (h) Qualified professionals and support personnel at FGS MOLSA (2 Programme Coordinators + 3 TAs + 1 Communication Officer + 1 Finance Officer + 6 Regional Coordinators) continued to support FGS MoLSA and Somaliland MESAF; (i) At least bi-monthly coordination meetings with the stakeholders held at federal and regional levels; (j) At least 6 monitoring visits to the project sites undertaken and reports produced to take corrective measures; (k) Two (2) Project Steering Committee (PSC) meetings held; (l) Two (2) monitoring missions supported to regional programme locations/sites; (m) High quality quarterly and final progress reports; (n) Evaluation of the programme and implementation of recommendations; (o) The 2nd generation programme document developed and agreed, with at least US $5m mobilized/committed; (p) All plans (AWP, Procurement, HR, M&E) in place; (q) 100% project delivery rate; (r) At least 2 project coordination meetings participated and substantially contributed; (s) All the planned activities implemented effectively and final report developed timely.

(a) 24 fishery MSME/cooperatives set up and functional in Bossaso (12), Kismayo (6) and Berbera (6). (b) 120 youth (70 women), having acquired entrepreneurial and vocational skills, micro-grants, BDS services, were self-employed through the 24 fishery MSMEs, managed by them. (c) 3 HACCP guidelines/SOPs on seafood safety for Jubaland, Puntland and Somaliland developed in English and Somali and endorsed by the respective regional authorities. Over 150 government officials, representatives from the fishery associations and businesses were oriented on the seafood safety and regulations in Puntland, Jubaland and Somaliland. (d) In Mogadishu, Kismayo and Baidoa, a total 384 unemployed young people (178 women) improved their market-oriented skills in solar panel installation and maintenance and entrepreneurship skills development through a 3-month tailor-made training programme. Their employability was increased through provision of certificates and startup solar tool kits. (e) 50 trained youth (50% women) employed and earned adequate income through job placement scheme in 12 well-established solar companies in Mogadishu and Kismayo. Out of the total trained youth, 30 young people (15 women) were wage-employed in different companies in Mogadishu and Kismayo. (f) 48 trained youth (50% women) became self-employed and were earning adequate income by setting up their 16 MSMEs - Mogadishu (12 SMEs, involving 36 youth), and Kismayo (4 SMEs, involving 12 youth). (g) The trained young people electrified 52 households (35 in Mogadishu and 17 in Kismayo); as a result, these household had access to affordable off-grid solar energy. (h) Qualified professionals and support personnel at FGS MOLSA (2 Programme Coordinators + 3 Tech Advisers + 1 Communication Officer + 1 Finance Officer + 6 Regional Coordinators +3 interns) continued to build capacities of FGS MoLSA and Somaliland MESAF in employment-related coordination and programming. (i) 6 employment-related coordination meetings held at federal and regional levels and minutes developed and shared for action. (j) At regional level, MOLSA line ministries undertook 6 monitoring visits to the project sites and submitted their reports with recommendations for action. International Youth Day was observed in 6 regions, such as Benadir, Jubaland, SWS, Puntland, Galmudug, Hirshabele and Somaliland - over 500 young women and men participated in different youth leadership initiatives, such as job fair, cleaning of surroundings, cultural shows, etc.A national employment council forum was held - this was chaired by the Minister, FGS MOLSA and participated by line ministries from 6 regions - meeting concluded with a decision to set up a national employment council and hold regular meetings. (k) 4 PSC meetings, 3 HoA meetings, 6 TWG meetings and 2 JPYES coordination meetings held. (l) JPYES Coordination team undertook 2 site visits to Puntland and Somaliland. (m) Semi-annual MPTF progress reports developed and shared.(n) JPYES Final Evaluation Report, with recommendations, Management Response, Evaluation Brief and success stories developed and endorsed. (o) 2nd generation programme document on employment developed for resource mobilization. (p) As part of the south-south cooperation, 32 high level MOLSA officials, including ministers and DGs from federal and regional line ministries, the Chamber of Commerce, participated in a study tour to Ethiopia for knowledge sharing on how to address the employment and social protection issues. (q) All the planned activities implemented. (r) the project delivery rate, at present, stands at 85%.

OUTPUT 1.2: (a) A HACCP Certification - the Standard Operating Procedures/guidelines on seafood safety developed for Puntland, Jubaland and Somaliland; (b) At least 50 officials (25 women) from fishery ministries and other stakeholders trained in good practices of HACCP and their knowledge improved in 3 districts; (c) Fish processing facilities - in Kismayo 3, Berbera 2 - set up/constructed; (d) 24 fish enterprises set up/strengthened - employed 120 youth in Bossaso, Berbera and Kismayo. OUTPUT 2.2: (a) 400 unemployed and underemployed youth (200 from Mogadishu, 100 each from Kismayo and Baidoa, with at least 30% women) trained in solar energy and business development skills; (b) 50 trained youth (at least 30% women) employed and earning adequate income through job placement scheme; (c) 50 trained youth (at least 30% women) self-employed by setting up/strengthening their 20 businesses. OUTPUT 2.3: (a) MOLSA capacity in planning, coordination, M&E and oversight functions improved, with regular coordination meetings between FGS and Regions; (b) Qualified professional staff available at leadership level at FGS MOLSA (5 TAs, 4 Interns, 1 Job Creation Specialist, 1 Communication Officer) and 5 Regional State MOLSA/MOY&S (6 TEs). OUTPUT 3.2: (a) 1,000 youth (at least 30% women) got short-term job opportunities; (b) At least 5 public places cleaned and beautified; (c) At least 1 infrastructure rehabilitated. OUTPUT 4: (a) Four Project Steering Committee meetings held; (b) Four YES events supported; (c) 5 monitoring missions undertaken and reports developed and shared; (d) Seven Technical Working Group meetings held and reports developed; (e) Semi-annual progress reports developed and shared; (f) YES phase II programme document drafted and endorsed for implementation OUTPUT 5: (a) 100% project delivery rate; (b) Required project staff recruited and managed well; (c) All plans (AWP, Procurement, HR and M&E) are developed and implemented; (d) Semi-annual reports developed.

OUTPUT 1.2: Key interventions implemented to improve their long-term potential for growth, productivity and employment: • In collaboration with the local authorities and FAO, the Standard Operating Procedures (SOP)/guidelines on seafood safety have been developed for Puntland, Jubaland and Somaliland. An official documentation for seafood export has developed to meet requirements of importing countries. Over 60 officials (10 women) from public and private sectors and fisherfolks have been trained on the sanitary handling of seafood, hygiene and its environment in 3 districts. • 10 Fish processing facilities – 5 in Bossaso, 3 in Kismayo and 2 in Berbera – set up by UNDP and are being equipped by FAO. • 90 unemployed trained fisherfolks (50 women) from the disadvantaged groups have trained on how to set up and improve their businesses in fishery sector and have access to revolving funds to set up their 18 cooperatives in Bossaso and Kismayo. The capacities of selected 2 local institutions, that would provide Business Development Services (BDS) to 18 cooperatives, have been strengthened in Mogadishu and Kismayo.
OUTPUT 2.2: Programme of vocational, business and life skills training provided • 48 unemployed trained young people (25 women) from the disadvantaged groups have been trained on how to set up and improve their businesses in solar sector and have access to revolving funds to set up their 16 cooperatives in Mogadishu and Kismayo. The capacities of selected 2 local institutions, that would provide Business Development Services (BDS) to 16 solar enterprises, have been strengthened in Mogadishu and Kismayo.
OUTPUT 2.3: Capacity of ministries and institutions for the collections, analysis and storage of labour market data and youth employment programming development • It was noticed that the government counterparts are more aware of their roles and responsibilities, especially in coordination, M&E and oversight roles. Several government counterparts at regional levels have taken the initiatives to monitor and review the ongoing YES activities and have organized the multi-stakeholder coordination meetings. It has been noticed that the local authorities have led the planning and implementation of YES project activities at their level. At federal level, MoLSA has organized coordination meetings, having invited regional counterparts to review the YES programme as well as development of the phase II YES concept note. • MoLSA has recruited all the required 20 programme and support personnel who have provided advisory and programme management support to the ministries at federal and regional levels.
OUTPUT 3.2: Urban infrastructure projects implemented (roads, environmental works, storage facilities, markets, etc.) • By creating 78,000 workdays, job opportunities for 1,000 young people (400 women) have been created, through labour-intensive public works in 17 districts of Benadir Region. 17 public places, such as streets, parks, public infrastructure, etc. in 17 districts, have been cleaned and beautified. Through intensive campaign and neighbourhood watch initiative, the knowledge of personal hygiene, safety and security improved amongst the communities. It is estimated that 150,000 residents in Benadir Region benefitted from such initiatives. • The solar streetlight infrastructure - of over 15 km street, that is from Sana’a to Tarabuunka street and from Fagah to X-milk factory street that crosses 13 districts out of 17 in Benadir- is now lighted and functional, by rehabilitating 190 solar poles, installing solar panels and batteries. As a result, it is estimated that around 1 million people are benefitting from such rehabilitation; the residents are feeling safer at night and the businesses are continuing to open at night at the project sites. • The capacity of Benadir City Administration has been developed to keep the Mogadishu city clean, by providing 2 storm-drain cleaning trucks and 2 skid steer loaders for rubbish collection to the above administration.
OUTPUT 4: Overall JP YES Programme coordinated effectively and efficiently • The independent mid-term evaluation report of JPYES was developed and endorsed by the Project Steering Committee meeting, held on 1st March; and all the PUNOs agreed to implement the recommendations highlighted in the report. • To commemorate the International Youth Day on 12th August, 5 regional states, such as Jubaland, South West State, Hirshabelle and Galmudug organized job fairs which were participated by hundreds of young entrepreneurs, who exhibited their skills, products and services in a spectacular gathering in each region. The events were attended by well-established employers/businesses, high level government officials, youth and other residents. • The Minister of Youth and Sports, Her Excellency Ms. Khadijo Mohamed Diriye, her advisor and a representative of a civil society participated a 7th UN Youth Forum, entitled “The Role of Youth in Building Sustainable and Resilient Urban and Rural Communities”, held in New York during 30th-31 January 2018. The Somalia delegation was able to present the country’s achievements on youth development within the framework of 2013 Agenda for Sustainable Development. • In 2018, 3 Project Steering Committee (PSC) meetings were held in 10th April, 12th June and 24th October and reviewed the JPYES progress, achievements, endorsing the mid-term evaluation report, endorsing the work plans and other matters. The minutes of the meetings were developed, endorsed and disseminated to all the partners. 3 Head of Agencies (HoA) meetings were also held in April and October, prior to the Steering Committee meetings, that reviewed some pertinent issues and took action for addressing them, accordingly. Similarly, 5 Technical Working Groups (TWGs) meetings were held on 1st March, 5th April, 8th May, 20 August and 22nd October, and reviewed the YES progress and took decisions. At the regional level, 6 Regional Coordination Meetings/workshops were held in different regions on 12th April, 22nd April, 28th August, 24th September, 28th November. In these meetings, the Regional Coordinators participated and reviewed the progress of YES. A donor consultative meeting was held in Nairobi in July, to brief on the JPYES progress and achievements, while looking into the possibility for resource mobilization. • 5 joint monitoring missions were undertaken in different dates to Baidoa, Kismayo, Puntland, Benadir, and Somaliland and the ongoing activities were monitored, reviewed and reports, with reconditions, developed and disseminated with the partners to take action. • A consolidated semi-annual report was developed and shared with the partners in July 2018. • Through a multi-stakeholder consultative process, held in 6 regions, a consolidated concept note for the YES-II was developed to be submitted to the PSC for their approval.
OUTPUT 5: UNDP-implemented YES Project managed effectively and efficiently • The YES Project delivery rate stands at 95%. All the required professional and support staff recruited. All the required plans, such as AWPs, procurement plans, HR plan and M&E plan were developed and implemented effectively. The quality semi-annual report of YES Project was developed timely. The YES Project Team, through working closely with the government counterparts and other stakeholders and providing tailor-made trainings, developed capacities of the implementing partners in RBM programming, coordination and financial management. The Project team actively participated in the planning consultative process for designing of YES-II.
